extensions.title: Build an Extension for haex-vault
extensions.subtitle: Learn how to create powerful extensions using the official SDK. This guide walks you through the complete process from setup to publishing.

overview.title: Overview
overview.intro: The haex-vault SDK provides a complete framework for building secure, cryptographically-signed extensions. Extensions run in sandboxed environments with granular permissions, ensuring user data stays protected while enabling powerful functionality.

database.title: Database Access
database.description: Full SQLite database with migrations, CRDT sync support, and Drizzle ORM integration.

security.title: Cryptographic Security
security.description: Ed25519 signing, permission-based access control, and sandboxed execution.

frameworks.title: Framework Support
frameworks.description: Native adapters for Vue, React, Svelte, and vanilla JavaScript.

distribution.title: Easy Distribution
distribution.description: Sign, package, and publish to the marketplace with simple CLI commands.

prerequisites.title: Prerequisites
prerequisites.nodejs: JavaScript runtime for building your extension

quickstart.title: Quick Start
quickstart.intro: Get a new extension up and running in just a few minutes. We'll use Vite with Vue, but you can use any framework.

step1.title: Create Project & Install SDK
step1.description: This creates a new Vite project, installs the SDK, and initializes the extension structure including manifest and cryptographic keys.

step2.title: Protect Your Private Key
step2.description: The haex init command creates a private.key file in the haextension folder. This key is used to sign your extension.

warning.title: Security Warning
warning.description: Never commit your private.key to version control. Add it to .gitignore immediately. If you lose this key, you'll need to generate a new one and your extension's identity will change.

step3.title: Start Development
step3.description: Start the Vite dev server and load your extension in haex-vault for live development.

projectStructure.title: Project Structure
projectStructure.intro: After initialization, your project will have the following structure:

manifest.title: Extension Manifest
manifest.intro: The manifest.json file defines your extension's metadata, permissions, and configuration. It's the heart of your extension.

fields.title: Field Reference
fields.name: Unique identifier for your extension (lowercase, hyphens allowed)
fields.publicKey: Your Ed25519 public key (generated by haex init)
fields.entry: HTML entry point relative to the build output
fields.singleInstance: If true, only one instance can run at a time

sdkSetup.title: SDK Integration
sdkSetup.intro: The SDK provides framework-specific adapters for seamless integration. Choose your framework below to see the setup code.

tip.title: Tip
tip.description: The SDK automatically handles communication with haex-vault, context changes, and error handling. Just import and use the composable/hook.

database.title: Database
database.intro: Extensions have access to a SQLite database with automatic table namespacing. Your tables are prefixed with your public key to prevent conflicts with other extensions.

migrations.title: Migrations
migrations.description: Define your database schema using migrations. Migrations run automatically and are tracked to prevent duplicate execution.

crdt.title: Reserved Columns
crdt.description: haex-vault automatically adds CRDT sync columns (haex_timestamp, haex_column_hlcs, haex_deleted) to all tables. Do not create columns starting with 'haex_' as they will be overwritten.

drizzle.title: Drizzle ORM Integration
drizzle.description: For type-safe queries, you can use Drizzle ORM with the SDK's built-in integration.

storage.title: Key-Value Storage
storage.intro: For simple data that doesn't need database features, use the Storage API. It provides a localStorage-like interface scoped to your extension.

filesystem.title: Filesystem Access
filesystem.intro: Extensions can save and open files through the Filesystem API. All operations show native dialogs to the user for security.

webRequests.title: HTTP Requests
webRequests.intro: Make HTTP requests to external APIs using the Web API. All requests must be to URLs declared in your manifest permissions.

permissions.title: Permissions
permissions.intro: Extensions must declare all required permissions in the manifest. Users review and approve these permissions during installation.

operations.title: Permission Types
operations.httpDescription: Use glob patterns to specify allowed URLs. Use ** for path wildcards and * for single segment wildcards.

context.title: Application Context
context.intro: Access the current theme, locale, and platform information. The context updates automatically when the user changes settings.

buildSign.title: Build & Sign
buildSign.intro: When you're ready to distribute your extension, build it and sign it with your private key.

warning.title: Important
warning.description: Keep your private key safe and backed up. If you lose it, you cannot update your extension and will need to publish as a new extension with a different identity.

publish.title: Publishing
publish.intro: Share your extension with the haex.space community through the marketplace.

step1.title: Test Thoroughly
step1.description: Test your extension on all platforms you want to support. Check permissions work correctly.

step2.title: Prepare Assets
step2.description: Create screenshots, write a compelling description, and prepare your extension icon.

step3.title: Submit to Marketplace
step3.description: Upload your .haextension file to the marketplace with your listing details.

step4.title: Review Process
step4.description: Our team reviews extensions for security and quality. Typical review time is 2-3 business days.
